rev.comment: reversion to mgunn. let others decide
/* Current discriminatory practices */ this is alleged, not fact. I don't think there is anything close to agreement on what is a "discriminatory network practice"
Following Wikipedia:Lead Section, the introduction should have text "describing its notable controversies" This 1 sentence should remain.
rv: some of category changes do not appear to make sense
/* Uses of non-neutral networks */ remove sentence in other place
Following Wikipedia:Lead Section, the introduction should have text "describing its notable controversies" This 1 sentence should remain.
regulation is not all there is to the political efforts
/* The debate */ format, principle name change
more equals signs to make readable
removed 'access to data network resources' which is a meaningless overly generic term
/* Law outside the U.S. */ removed uncited claim (I believe it to be false in fact, but it's uncited anyway)
/* Types of discriminatory practice */ removed uncited section
removed uncited claim about what constitutes NN
rv: NPOV... NPOV is achieved by collecting notable opinions not removing opinions you don't agree with.
POV hello! this is a deceptively pro tiering article about net neutrality!!!
moved the new problem solutions quote to the section non-neutrality section/* Non-neutral networks in problematic situations */
Please provide citations for direct quotations
/* Problems arising from apparent failures to retain a neutral network */
removed uncited and doubtless wrong claim that regulations are only a US issue
/* Current discriminatory practices */ removed redundant word ("bandwidth") [that already occurs 5 words later in same sentence].

revert: can you say "whitewash"? I knew you could!
/* Websites and articles opposing net neutrality */
tim wu's definition does not prohibit qos
disambiguate and simplify (VOIP isn't particularly high bandwidth anyway)
intro clean up spelling, structure, repeated words, clarification of purpose

/* Discriminatory Practices and violations of network neutrality */
/* Discriminatory Practices and violations of network neutrality */

/* Recent regulatory developments in the US */
/* Municipal Wireless, Powerline, 3GPP, and WiMax Broadband */ fixed Commerce Clause link
/* Quality of Service and Internet Protocols */ Wikilink to QoS
added globalize, the article deals exclusively with US issues
reword fist sentence to remove cicularity (neutrality says...neutral...is when...)
revise lead and restore Weinberger quote in a different place.
Removed 2nd paragraph that says NN's meaning is unclear because applying it is hard. Also changed NN from "regulation" to "policy."
/* Defininitions of network neutrality */ spelling error
/* External links */ delete inappropriate comtechnews.net links per [[WP:EL]]
network neutrality is broadly about delivering internet access fairly, but precisely what is and isn't fair is argued.
/* Discriminatory Practices and violations of network neutrality */
it's actually not ''too'' bad, but you need a whole heap of cites, also we must reintroduce TBLs definition (a sidebar might be nice), it is very notable.
Remove dangling reference to silly quote
Put one honest quote in the lead and remove activist nonsense
Bring lead info compliance with Wikipedia guidelines, and shelve the vandalism
revert vandalism to wolfkeeper (3 bad faith edits, removing fact tag, still mischaracterising Weinbergers position etc.) [it wasn't even my misspelling!]
rv - explain "why the subject is interesting or notable, and describing its notable controversies, if there are any", That's the rules for the lead.

revert: + removed 'intractable claim' he didn't say that, nor can his comments be construed that way from the cite. Reverted removal of 'fact' tag. Reverted false claim it is completely undefined term
rv spin - the Weinberger statement is the most honest thing that's every been said about NN
simply not notable enough to be in the lead. (leads should be about 4 paragraphs long)
removed uncited claim, plus make clear that TBL is defining the term; added cite as to what exactly that part of the regulation does actually mean
Sharpen the contrast for the untutored audience
Replace passive construction and cite Google's partner
Move Wikipedia editor Weinberger's quote to the close of the lede to make the preceeding text more accessible to the untutored audience
Flesh out the contrast in the two main views for the untutored audience.
Explain what TBL is trying to say for the untutored audience
Replace contributions which were removed without good reason
Tim Berners Les's definition is reasonably precise, so I don't think you can claim that it has ''no'' precise meaning; there is atleast one notable one.
removed uncited claim that 'this view is not widespread'- it may well be true or not; but you would need to cite it very well to add it (particularly) here.
make quote from law more readable by eliding redundant language
Introduce more balance in opening paragraph and correct the incorrect and over-simplified view.
Flag Berners-Lee's theory as idiosyncratic and cite the actual law. This is a US-centric issue, as no other country has such laws.

NPOV, style, accuracy- that's isn't what Network Neutrality is, whether or not certain US-centric legislation has that effect or not; (the first paragraph in a page defines something, not its effects)
Ah, gone for the full spin, are we? Revert.
Get my proper login in here so nobody cries "Sockpuppet!"
If there is going to be one quotation in the lede, there should be two, one on each side. But Google won't permit that, so lose theirs to avoid the NNPOV.
/* See also */ added [[Internet Freedom and Nondiscrimination Act of 2006]]
added fact tag- IMO that isn't what the law says
Moved down to the US-centric part (it's not an inherent part of NN, other countries don't make this particular requirement) as noted:[[Network neutrality#Neutrality as law]]. removed casual language
I see we have a little pest running around here making false claims. The legislation is now referenced for all sane people to see.
Remove sweeping, uncited -- and unknowable, really -- claim of what all lawmakers think.
I'll give you revolutionary and new, but not your fundamental deception.
removed weasel words that implies that all lawmakers insist on a single QOS. In fact most legislatilon permits multiple levels, but may not permit charging extra for such.
Removed unreferenced claim that it is revolutionary and new
Restore some balance in the lede as the Wolfkeeper form is guided by a NNPOV.
/* Discriminatory Practices and violations of network neutrality */
/* Discriminatory Practices and violations of network neutrality */
/* Websites and articles supporting net neutrality */
more specific link to TBL blog entry
link to mit edu site, and TBL official blog link
/* "Dumb" versus "intelligent" networks */ used different quote from source
revert changes by sockpuppet of suspended user, undo ridiculously paranoid copyvio
Rm links to suspected copy-vio or otherwise inappropriate links per WP:EL & WP:C using [[WP:AWB|AWB]]

rv - Richard, what you're selling, no one is really buying.
rv Rank bias. Save the Internet cites many definitions, but only put one into their bills. No need to mislead here.
partial rv to Carlton: NPOV, notability of primary definition (Crawford's is not used by savetheinternet for example)
/* Discriminatory Practices and violations of network neutrality */ added links; tweaked wording to be less aggressive and expanded colloquial shortening of terms.
"vandalism"? Richard, you need to buy a good dictionary.
Restore the facts that Google doesn't want you to know
clearly network neutrality is incompatible with network tiering, no reference to (rejected) legislation really supports this well. Crawford simply conflates competition and NN; not notable to lead.

more specific reference to TBL comments on network neutrality
Wolfy says it's an "idealized concept" and I agree with him/her. Let's share that understanding with the world.
Nework neutrality is not in itself a controversy, it is a idealised concept; the controversy is about whether, how, where and when it should/shouldn't be implemented.
cleaned up lead, moved debate into debate section
Correct misstatement of telegraph network and highlight third force
not necessarily (typification can occur in many ways, telegrams carried many different types of traffic)
The lede is for broad definitions, not details of particular law
